block.p: Companies

Leaders of some of the nation's largest law firms disagreed whether Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler needed to settle a Federal ethics lawsuit quickly. But the firm said it was faced with possible collapse if it waited. [ Page A1. ]
Companies

Leaders of some of the nation's largest law firms disagreed whether Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler needed to settle a Federal ethics lawsuit quickly. But the firm said it was faced with possible collapse if it waited. [ Page A1. ]
Michael Milken, hundreds of other former Drexel executives, and Drexel's insurers will put up $1.3 billion to settle all civil litigation against them. [ D1. ]
J. P. Morgan said it lost $50 million on mortgage-backed securities so far this year and that the head of the unit that trades in the investments had resigned. [ D1. ]
The Alexander's department store chain is negotiating with its banks for easier credit terms. [ D1. ]
Keycorp, the Albany-based banking company, agreed to buy Puget Sound Bancorp, a big bank in Washington state. [ D1. ]
A "consummate strategist" has given Hewlett-Packard a commanding position in the laser printer market. [ D1. ]
Pratt & Whitney won a $160 million order from Delta Air Lines for 18 jet engines. [ D4. ]
Revco, the bankrupt drugstore chain, is on the verge of emerging from Chapter 11 protection. [ D4. ]
Rambus, a Silicon Valley start-up, has developed a technology to increase vastly the speed of memory chips and computers and has licensed the information to Japanese companies. [ D8. ]
The Christian Science Church put its cable television channel up for sale after the chuch's chairman resigned. [ A16. ]
Major League Baseball is close to an agreement for a line of credit worth $300 million with Citibank and other lenders. [ B9. ] The Economy
Venture capital funds, bloated in the mid-1980's but famished for the last few years, are again enticing investors. [ D1. ]
The nation's banks earned $18.6 billion last year, a 15 percent increase over 1990, even though 11 big banks lost money. [ D3. ]
Senators and their aides are guessing what amendments will be proposed right after the Senate takes up tax legislation today and which will be conspicuous by their absence. [ D7. ]
Consumer credit outstanding fell three-tenths of 1 percent in January, but consumers increased their car loans. [ D17. ] International
Developing countries that follow I.M.F. programs usually make big cuts in welfare spending and tax rates. [ D2. ]
The ease with which Robert Maxwell plundered employee pension funds shows that Britain's regulatory system needs to be greatly strengthened, a Parliamentary report said. [ D22. ] Markets
Stocks closed mixed in thin trading. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 6.48 points, to 3,215.12. [ D10. ]
Treasury notes and bonds rose in price, continuing the rally that began Friday. [ D18. ]
The dollar settled mostly lower in quiet profit taking on world currency markets. Gold slumped worldwide. [ D19. ]
Wheat futures prices rose sharply amid prospects for overnight frost damage in areas growing winter wheat. [ D19. ] Today's Columns
The Surgeon General and the American Medical Association demanded that R. J. Reynolds stop using the cartoon character Joe Camel in its Camel cigarette ads. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ A1. ]
The social forces that made New York subways a marvel in the early 20th century are still at work in Moscow's subway. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene [ D2. ]
Ionics appears to have a bright future in the business of purifying water. Market Place. [ D10. ]
